contentrichtext.text: {{for|the American screen actor sometimes billed as Richard Haynes|Dick Haynes}} {{for|the Australian clarinettist Richard Haynes|Richard Haynes (musician)}} '''Richard "Racehorse" Haynes''' (born April 3, 1927) is a [[Texas]] [[criminal defense attorney]]. ''[[TIME]]'' magazine once referred to him as one of the top six [[criminal lawyer]]s in America. ==Military record== Richard Haynes served in the United States Marine Corps during World War II. He participated in the [[Battle of Iwo Jima]] at the age of seventeen. In that battle, U.S. Marines hit the beach from small landing crafts under heavy enemy fire. While on the beach and firing at the Japanese, Haynes noticed a fellow Marine still in the water and wounded. Haynes left his position on the beach while under heavy enemy machine gun, mortar and artillery fire, went back into the water, picked up the wounded Marine, and brought him to a safer position on the beach where a Navy Corpsman came to the Marine's aid, saving his life. Haynes was decorated with a medal for his heroic actions during the battle. ==Law practice== A native of [[Houston, Texas|Houston]], [[Texas]], he graduated from the [[University of Houston Law Center]] in 1956, and was admitted to the State Bar of Texas on April 23, 1956.<ref>Record, Richard Haynes, State Bar of Texas.</ref>He has been involved in [[landmark case]]s such as [[The State of Texas v. John Hill]] (a basis for the book ''[[Blood and Money]]''), and the notorious [[T. Cullen Davis]] [[murder]] and later [[solicitation]] of murder [[trial (law)|trials]] in [[Fort Worth]], [[Texas]], both of which ended in acquittals. He also represented [[Morganna]], a.k.a. "The Kissing Bandit" and Vickie Daniel, who was the wife of [[Price Daniel, Jr.]]. At a late 1970s [[American Bar Association]] seminar in New York [http://www.excaliburautomobile.com/Image/Circle&Sword/Vol3/page5.htm], Mr. Haynes explained how to [[Alternative pleading|plead in the alternative]]: <blockquote> Say you sue me because you say my dog bit you. Well, now this is my defense: * My dog doesn't bite. * And second, in the alternative, my dog was tied up that night. * And third, I don't believe you really got bit. * And fourth, I don't have a dog. </blockquote> Haynes resides in and practices law in [[Houston, Texas|Houston]]. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} <!-- for current and future use if material is uploaded --> * [http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/not_guilty/t_cullen_davis/4.html?sect=14 Racehorce Haynes] - a [[Court TV]] profile * ''The Wall Street Journal'', Tuesday, October 31, 1978, reprinted spring 1980 in a small circulation [http://www.excaliburautomobile.com/Pages/Circle&SwordUS.htm magazine], available [http://www.excaliburautomobile.com/Image/Circle&Sword/Vol3/page5.htm here]. * [http://www.uh.edu/pride-stories/richard-haynes/index.php University of Houston: Alum Richard Haynes Creaes ALegal Legacy] <br/><!--this break is to put visual space between the last information and the following template if needed--> {{Authority control|VIAF=52964835}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Haynes, Richard | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = April 3, 1927 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haynes, Richard}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:American lawyers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Houston alumni]] [[Category:University of Houston Law Center alumni]] [[Category:Criminal defense lawyers]]
